content.title: Migraine Prevention Therapy
content.summary: Migraine prevention aims to reduce attack frequency, severity, and duration when patients have ≥4 headache days/month, significant disability, or failure of acute treatments. Options include oral preventives (beta-blockers, anticonvulsants, antidepressants), CGRP monoclonal antibodies, and non-pharmacologic approaches (biofeedback, cognitive behavioral therapy).
key_points: Indication: ≥4 migraine days/month, significant disability, overuse of acute medications, or failure/contraindication to acute therapy
First-line oral options: propranolol, topiramate, amitriptyline, valproate; evidence-based efficacy
CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab): effective, well-tolerated, monthly or quarterly dosing
OnabotulinumtoxinA: approved for chronic migraine (≥15 headache days/month); specific injection protocol
Lifestyle modifications: regular sleep, hydration, stress management, avoiding triggers
Success defined as ≥50% reduction in migraine days after 2-3 months of adequate trial
content.statement: Effective migraine prevention reduces disease burden and improves quality of life. Treatment selection should be individualized based on comorbidities, side effect profiles, patient preferences, and insurance coverage.

explanation.intuition: Preventive medications work through various mechanisms to raise the migraine threshold, making attacks less likely to occur. Beta-blockers reduce sympathetic activity; topiramate modulates ion channels; amitriptyline affects serotonin/norepinephrine; CGRP antibodies block a key migraine signaling molecule released during attacks.
explanation.key_insight: CGRP monoclonal antibodies represent a paradigm shift - they are the first migraine-specific preventive therapy. Unlike oral preventives with broad mechanisms and significant side effects, CGRP antibodies target migraine pathophysiology directly with excellent tolerability. However, cost and access remain barriers.
explanation.technical_details: Adequate trial: 2-3 months at target dose before determining efficacy. Start low, titrate slowly for oral preventives. Goal is ≥50% reduction in migraine days. CGRP antibodies: erenumab (70-140mg SC monthly), fremanezumab (225mg monthly or 675mg quarterly), galcanezumab (240mg loading then 120mg monthly).

definitions_glossary.migraine_prevention: Prophylactic treatment to reduce frequency, severity, and duration of migraine attacks
definitions_glossary.cgrp: Calcitonin gene-related peptide: neuropeptide released during migraine attacks; therapeutic target
definitions_glossary.episodic_migraine: < 15 headache days/month; may still benefit from prevention if frequent or disabling
definitions_glossary.chronic_migraine: ≥ 15 headache days/month for ≥3 months, with ≥8 migraine days; different treatment approach
definitions_glossary.medication_overuse_headache: Headache from frequent acute medication use (≥10-15 days/month); requires detoxification
definitions_glossary.erenumab: CGRP receptor antagonist monoclonal antibody; monthly subcutaneous injection
definitions_glossary.fremanezumab: CGRP ligand antibody; monthly or quarterly dosing option
definitions_glossary.galcanezumab: CGRP ligand antibody; approved for migraine and cluster headache prevention
definitions_glossary.onabotulinumtoxinA: Botox: approved for chronic migraine; specific injection protocol (31 sites)
definitions_glossary.propranolol: Non-selective beta-blocker; first-line preventive with Level A evidence
definitions_glossary.topiramate: Anticonvulsant; effective migraine preventive; weight loss and cognitive side effects
definitions_glossary.amitriptyline: Tricyclic antidepressant; useful when insomnia or depression comorbid

pathophysiology.mechanism: Migraine involves trigeminal activation with release of CGRP and other neuropeptides, causing neurogenic inflammation and pain. Preventive therapies either reduce cortical excitability (anticonvulsants), modulate neurotransmitter systems (antidepressants, beta-blockers), or directly block CGRP signaling (monoclonal antibodies). The goal is to increase the threshold for triggering migraine attacks.
key_pathways: Beta-blockers: reduce sympathetic activity, possibly affecting trigeminovascular system
Topiramate: modulates GABA, glutamate, and voltage-gated channels; reduces cortical excitability
Amitriptyline: inhibits serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake; modulates pain pathways
CGRP mAbs: block CGRP or its receptor, preventing vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Without prevention, frequent migraines can progress to chronic migraine and medication overuse headache. Effective prevention breaks this cycle and may improve long-term prognosis.

indications_for_prevention: Overuse of acute medications (risk of MOH)
Failure, contraindication, or adverse effects from acute treatments
Uncommon migraine subtypes (hemiplegic, with prolonged aura, brainstem aura)

evaluation_of_efficacy.timeline: 2-3 months at target dose before assessing response
evaluation_of_efficacy.monitoring: Headache diary to track frequency, severity, acute medication use

cgrp_monoclonal_antibodies.advantages: Migraine-specific, well-tolerated, rapid onset, monthly/quarterly dosing
cgrp_monoclonal_antibodies.limitations: Cost, insurance requirements for prior authorization, injection site reactions

onabotulinumtoxinA.protocol: 155 units divided among 31 injection sites (PREEMPT protocol) every 12 weeks
onabotulinumtoxinA.efficacy: Reduces headache days by ~2/month vs placebo

skos.definition: Prophylactic treatment strategies to reduce the frequency, severity, and duration of migraine attacks in patients with frequent or disabling migraines

learning_objectives: Identify patients who are candidates for migraine prevention therapy
Select appropriate preventive medication based on comorbidities and contraindications
Describe the mechanism and advantages of CGRP monoclonal antibodies
Apply criteria for assessing preventive treatment efficacy
Recognize medication overuse headache and its role in prevention decisions
clinical_pearls: ≥4 migraine days/month = consider prevention; severity and disability also matter
Start low, go slow with oral preventives; give 2-3 month trial at target dose
Topiramate: cognitive side effects ('dopamax'); word-finding difficulty; kidney stones; weight loss
CGRP mAbs: may work when other preventives fail; constipation is most common side effect
OnabotulinumtoxinA: chronic migraine only; specific injection sites required (PREEMPT)
Avoid valproate in women of childbearing potential (teratogenic)
common_misconceptions: Prevention is only for chronic migraine (episodic migraine ≥4/month also benefits)
If one preventive fails, all will fail (different mechanisms; try 2-3 classes)
CGRP antibodies only for refractory cases (can be first-line if appropriate)
